name: Dance/Movement Therapy (DMT)
summary: A psychotherapeutic approach that uses movement and dance to promote emotional, cognitive, physical, and social integration.
description: Dance/Movement Therapy (DMT) is an expressive therapy that integrates movement, dance, and psychotherapeutic principles. It is based on the premise that the body and mind are interconnected, and movement can be a powerful tool for self-expression, healing, and growth. DMT is facilitated by trained therapists and can be used with individuals, groups, or families to improve mental health, enhance body awareness, support trauma recovery, and foster emotional regulation. Unlike recreational dance, DMT emphasizes the therapeutic process rather than performance.

metadata.training_required: Licensed or board-certified dance/movement therapist (varies by country).
metadata.regulatory_status: Recognized by professional bodies such as the American Dance Therapy Association (ADTA); regulatory oversight varies by country.

contraindications: Relative: Severe mobility limitations without adaptations, acute psychosis without stabilization
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe. Some individuals may need modifications based on mobility or medical conditions.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate. Increasing body of research supports its use for mental health, trauma, and rehabilitation, though more rigorous trials are needed.

sections.text: DMT is grounded in the principle that movement reflects emotional states and can influence psychological processes. By engaging in guided movement, clients can access unconscious material, release tension, build self-awareness, and improve emotional regulation. The therapist uses movement observation and interventions to facilitate therapeutic goals.

sections.preparation: Comfortable clothing and a safe, open space are recommended. No dance experience is required.
procedure: Warm-up and grounding through simple movement or breathwork
Verbal reflection with therapist to integrate experiences
sections.frequency: Typically weekly, though may vary by program.
sections.total_treatment_time: 8–20 weeks or longer depending on therapeutic goals.

items: Group DMT for social support and cohesion

uncommon: Overwhelm if traumatic material surfaces without support
rare: Physical injury if not adapted to client’s abilities

ideal_candidates: Individuals seeking alternative forms of psychotherapy
Clients who connect with movement or struggle with verbal expression
Children and adults with developmental or neurological challenges
screening_required: Assessment of mobility and medical conditions
Mental health evaluation to ensure appropriateness

lifestyle_recommendations: Use music and dance for stress relief

sections.insurance_coverage: Sometimes covered under mental health or rehabilitation services, depending on provider and region

items: DMT is distinct from recreational dance; it emphasizes therapeutic process, not performance.
Particularly valuable for clients who find it difficult to express emotions verbally.
Research supports benefits in trauma recovery, emotional regulation, and developmental conditions.

items.label: Koch SC, Kunz T, Lykou S, Cruz R. (2014). Effects of dance movement therapy and dance on health-related psychological outcomes: A meta-analysis. The Arts in Psychotherapy.

seo.title: Dance/Movement Therapy – Expressive Arts Psychotherapy
seo.description: Dance/Movement Therapy uses movement and dance as a psychotherapeutic tool to support emotional, cognitive, and social well-being.
